Text: Wag Waffle Bites would be a tasty, wholesome treat if it weren't for the titanium dioxide. "For color"??? The European Food Safety Authority has banned titanium dioxide as a food additive due to genotoxicity which may lead to carcinogenic effects. Titanium dioxide is fine for house paint, but I don't use titanium dioxide containing sun block because it's absorbed through the skin; and I'm certainly not going to feed it to my dog! And why would any canine desire a tasteless, white, opaque pigment in his food and why would any human wish to feed his/her loving companion a genotoxic, carcinogenic substance?
Location/Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2024

Text: Titanium dioxide can be harmful to dogs if ingested, and it's commonly found in pet food, treats, and supplements. In 2021, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) announced that titanium dioxide is no longer considered safe as a food additive for animals, including pets. The EFSA's Panel on Additives and Products or Substances used in Animal Feed (FEEDAP) concluded that titanium dioxide can accumulate in the body and may cause genetic toxicity, especially in long-lived or reproductive animals. The panel also couldn't rule out concerns about genotoxicity, which is a substance's ability to damage DNA.
Location/Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2024
